comments.commentBody:
Summary: A part of the ceiling fell in a store that didn't have customers in it at the time. Nobody was hurt. Shoppers were concerned that their plans to purchase things would be temporarily stymied.

In other news, 97 people were killed in Oslo, Norway, by radical extremists. Performer Amy Winehouse is dead at the age of 27.

No surprise here. Obama and Eric Holder don't care about black people. Well, they only care about black people who went to Harvard or are investment bankers at Goldman Sachs or Citibank. Obama and Holder are the worst combo since Reconstruction - they're just two house servants doing their master's bidding while the rest of us labor in the fields for pennies a day.

I hope Kei can find a valued home with a team that matches his talents.

But really, what's with the Japanese baseball players who refuse to learn English?

Walking with someone you know can be equally disconcerting, especially if you just happen to bump into them.  Trying to remain polite yet focused on getting to your destination as quickly as possible is an exercise in futility--RUN!

I wonder if the Irish feel attacked when this happens on St. Patrick's Day....lol...If the laws are not being broken and there are no fines to give out, then the police do not keep coming. Pretty simple if you ask me.
Congratulations to all. Enjoy your day. . .whenever it may be.

I am one of the officiants chosen to marry couples at the Popupchapel event. The couples assigned to me are committed and loving and ready to make this public demonstration of their personal relationship.I am happy to offer my services to them, and I think we all hope for the day when this will not be news.
Was Malcolm X too political and radical to merit the renewed attention of the federal government?

I don't care what the former transaction was; I don't really care even if the detective threw Dellutri to the ground.  Nothing justifies driving your car into a human being repeatedly.  It's attempted murder of a police officer and it should be prosecuted that way.
It's almost as catchy as Robert F. Kennedy Bridge.

#1:  Both of the stories you cited were reported.  There were people in this store at the time of the accident; the fact that they were not customers, I hope, does not relegate them to a lower status.

I, too, am astonished at these huffy comments of people who think they have a God-given right to barge up the escalators. You'll get there, folks ... maybe a few second later than you wanted, but you'll get there.

New York might have been a scruffier place when I came here in the 70s, but here's the funny thing: NOBODY would have even THOUGHT of doing this. The escalator was there to take you to the top without you having to walk: imagine that! In the mid-80s, this was still the case. I remember being astonished when I went to London and first encountered people walking up escalators (though, if memory serves me, I believe it was the right side). But, guess what: those escalators were TWICE as wide as those in New York, and you could pass people without smacking them in the shoulder as you passed, so it sort of made sense. Still, I was relieved to get back to New York, where having to be aware of what side you were standing on had not yet become a problem. Not long afterward, I was riding up an escalator at Lincoln Center behind a middle-aged tourist who worried that I might be in a greater hurry than she was. I reassured her that we might be in a hurry in New York, but an escalator was an escalator, and for one or two minutes, everyone was at the same pace. How things have changed!
Congratulations to All!
Little by little, chunks of the DOE's total control over the schools, are being checked. It is a small, but good sign.

I agree with all your film choices, plus one reader who mentioned "Marathon Man."  Another is "Manhattan," which is sort of a fairy tale image of affluent east side New York.  Ditto "An Unmarried Woman." However, for me, a truly evocative movie which captures life among middle class Jews in Brooklyn during WW2  was Woody Allen's "Radio Days."  Although I didn't live in New York at that time, I have a positive feeling it's totally authentic.  If you haven't seen it, please do.  It's a little masterpiece.

"...Republican zeal to lower debts could result in increased interest expenses and higher debts. Their mania to save taxpayers could cost taxpayers. That suggests not governance so much as fanaticism." Yet you don't have a problem with the President's zeal, mania and fanaticism for raising taxes in the middle of a prolonged recession and economic stagnation, which I think is much more threatening to our economy's ability to recover.

We are more likely to commit economic suicide if we follow the President. If we follow the Republicans, at least we have a chance to restore fiscal sanity and rebuild our nation's economy before we end up in the economic doldrums -- or worse -- of Europe.

The real problem lies in the fact that we have domestic zealots on both sides. While it's true that the conservatives go overboard on cutting everything in sight, including those things that make us more competitive, such as education and infrastructure, it's just as true that liberals have never seen a social welfare program that they're unwilling to sign up for, paid for by 58 cents of every federal dollar, the other 42 cents being debt.

Those that refuse to discuss new taxes may have it right, because there will never be a point at which liberals will see an end of the need to tax more and more, to fund newer and larger programs; not even when taxation at all levels consumes 100% of productive output in this country, and the government is simply re-distributing our entire GDP from the more productive to the less productive any way it sees fit -- and still printing make-believe money to pay for it all.

You have a problem with zealotry. Actually, so do I. But my problem is broader, because it encompasses both sides of the political divide. And I see no way to regain some semblance of fiscal sanity but the brinksmanship that is being practiced by those who have planted themselves in the ooze of Washington, D.C., and said "enough is enough".

We must not default. But the agreement that eventually keeps us from that fate, even if it's signed at midnight on 1 August, 2011, must be one that starts to place boundaries around what our government can do to some individuals in the name of saving other individuals.

During my forty year career as an egghead I’ve noticed that bright people are exasperated in the company of the dull and dull people are fearful in the company of smarties. That explains, I think, why the new Republican representatives are determined to make future generations dull. Being good parents, they don’t want their children to be afraid.

Why doesn't anybody get it?  Certain Republicans have been promised who-knows-what in return for not compromising on their "Pledge" not to raise taxes. Trouble is that Pledge they signed was not a "pledge", but a Contract. If they don't compromise, they get paid off, if they do, no pay-off. Simple, follow the money. "ATR" is a front for greedy/wealthy people who intend to make a fortune by gaming the markets while giving orders to the Republicans they own and control with their excessive wealth. Why is this so difficult to comprehend, people?

Reporter John Nichols described on NPR Fresh Air with Terry Gross earlier this week how powerful right wing forces such as Koch brothers, and A.L.E.C. are trying to grab power for corporations at the state level, which is less publicized nationally by the media. They are trying to turn the public services into private money makers. This is a takeover of govt basically. And all rationalized by slogans like free enterprise.

The psychology of the GOP right is bizarre. They are irresponsible, non contributing, non productive, and are confiscating the labor of others to appropriate the country’s wealth for themselves—the very things they accuse the lower classes of doing. They shift tax burdens to the lower earners. They accumulate wealth through financial manipulations and then bribe our govt. Then they assume a stance of moral outrage at how the rest of us are irresponsible and are ruining the economy.

When we taxed the rich higher they still had plenty of wealth, but we still had a successful country too. We built a middle and working class with social security, medicare, good paying jobs, unions, guaranteed retirement, available higher education--and we still had corporate expansion and profits.

What is the psychology of these fanatics so obsessed with paying no taxes, privatizing everything, and not contributing to the society? How did they develop such a radical, destructive philosophy? I guess once they assume superiority to the rest of us non deserving Americans, their underlying philosophy allows them to go further and further out into a vicious takeover mentality. They can’t give an inch, because that would open a crack in their defenses, and destroy their whole world view.

The right wing can outspend to get candidates for congress elected. How can they ever vote for publically financed elections? All the other modern countries have this And without breaking up big media conglomerates who control our conformist political discussion, alternate vo

Ahh, more name calling from the "tolerant" left. We've already been called racists, idiots and immoral by the left, so being called a zealot isn't so bad.

Maybe someday these "tolerant" people will be able to comment on those who disagree with them without the base name calling.

Do the folks at the Times really think they are any different than the folks at Fox News? If so, they need a heavy dose of reality.

After all we've been through with this, Saturday night it's come down to a pitiful "We'll call his bluff" response from Republicans.  That's all they can come up with.  You don't want to believe it but it's now crystal clear.  They do not have the maturity to govern this country.  What an appalling spectacle.

Interesting how every op-ed columnist has suddenly become an expert on the bond market, which is priced for a default risk of precisely zero.  President Obama has done a great job enlisting the NYC/DC establishment as part of his negotiating team, but the last time Congress was threatened with Armageddon (for $780B), at least Hank Paulson had to get on his knees to seal the deal.  This time the threat is exaggerated and Obama has acted in bad faith from the beginning of his presidency.  This is the time for him to finally show some conviction :  let him grovel.

In Haiti I'm gonna do plumbing, electrical, make tired folks laugh, play with kids, and wash and lotion old folks tired feet!! I cannot wait!! Sans bible, of course. And all of my friends who give me money, I will mention to the people I help, and figger out some way for them to thank them.
On March 16, 2006, all Democratic senators, including Sen. Barack Obama (D-IL), voted against raising the debt limit.  Naturally, Nicholas Kristof wrote a column questioning their patriotism.
